key_events.description: Analysts at BTG Pactual, Safra, and XP Investimentos have a neutral outlook on BBAS3 with price targets around R$ 25. BTG Pactual anticipates a payout of around 30% for 2026. The administration expects rural delinquency rates to peak in Q1 2026.

Banco do Brasil faces challenges in the agribusiness sector, including R$ 5.4 billion in delinquent loans from 808 producers and the deceleration of CPR origination. Safra estimates renegotiations under MP 1.314 (totaling R$ 12 billion) may extend into Q1 2026.
The payout for 2026 is expected to remain at 30%, potentially through JCP or dividends, paid in eight installments. The bank will prioritize JCP whenever possible.
BTG Pactual expects a slight sequential improvement in Q4 2025 results, with delinquency above 90 days continuing on an upward trajectory.
BTG Pactual downgraded Banco do Brasil from Buy to Neutral on May 19, 2025, with a target price of R$ 30.

risk_factors: New regulatory requirements pressuring capital ratios
Uncertainties regarding provisions due to the outlook for rural credit

investment_thesis.bull_case: Potential for extraordinary dividends in 2026 if the bank strengthens its capital base. Aim to disburse approximately R$ 25 billion under the MP 1.314.
investment_thesis.bear_case: Challenges in ROE due to persistent credit costs. Goldman Sachs highlights that Banco do Brasil faces the greatest uncertainties regarding provisions due to the outlook for rural credit. Safra reduced its profit projection for 2026 to R$ 22.187 billion, implying a Return on Equity (ROE) of 12.0%, which is 13% below consensus.

summary_markdown: BBAS3's outlook is cautiously neutral. BTG Pactual, Safra and XP Investimentos have neutral ratings with price targets around R$ 25 for 2026. Challenges persist in agribusiness, with R$ 5.4 billion in delinquent loans. The dividend payout is expected to remain at 30%. BTG Pactual downgraded BBAS3 to Neutral on May 19, 2025. Safra projects a 2026 profit of R$ 22.187 billion. The administration expects rural delinquency rates to peak in Q1 2026. Banco do Brasil aims to disburse approximately R$ 25 billion under the MP 1.314.
